boardgame.name: De Unesco-Regenboog
boardgame.description:
Card game published as a promotion for UNESCO. The tile means 'The Unesco Rainbow'.

The cards feature the letters U N E S C or O. There are eight of each letter and, in the main, they have different coloured backgrounds.

Each player, in turn, may lay a card on the table, that can legally go next to another card. There are none at the start so a U must be placed. After that, you may lay an N next to the U. You can place the N alongside the U or beneath it. The next player may now play a legal letter next to any card on the table. Thus, the word UNESCO will be spelt many times perhaps, horizentally or vertically. Think of it as a UNESCO crossword. If you cannot play a card, you draw one from the stock.

The first player to use all their cards wins the round. The other players total the value of cards left in their hands and take a score for them. Colour matches can matter because this makes a more penal score. After an agreed number of rounds, the player with the lowest score wins.

boardgame.name: Desert Ruins
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction

Long ago this castle buried under the desert's sand was one of many small fortifications guarding a caravan route running along the outskirts of a large desert. And while it withstood raiders and wars it had no chance against the ravages of time. Ever so slowly it was covered by the encroaching wandering dunes of the desert. Despite the best efforts of the garrison the castle's well fell dry, filled with sand and thus the castle had to be abandoned to be slowly covered by sand. Today as the large wandering dunes have passed what little remains of the castle has surfaced again, not much more than a small landmark among the endless dunes of the desert.

boardgame.name: Rope Bridges
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction

Only a short time ago the river that cut this canyon into the rocky ground was still flowing at its bottom. Then a nearby volcano violently erupted though. The river has been rerouted by the accompanying earthquakes and the streams of molten rock that are flowing in its old bed since then.

Crossing the canyon on the old rope bridges spanning its width via two rock pillars was at best perilous before the river far below was replaced by fast flowing lava. Now only the most hardened and desperate even dare considering such a venture. The heat wafting up is downright breathtaking and it has turned the ropes holding up the bridge dry and brittle.

boardgame.name: Motte
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction

The small stream flowing along in its bed has been the natural border between two realms for a long time. Recently relations between the two realms have turned sour and the ruler of one realm saw the need to establish a more formal border and to fortify it at the same time. For this reason he has started to construct small fortifications all along the former natural border.

Here a small moat, filled by the small river, has been dug and the excavated earth has been used to raise a small motte inside the moat. Its top is crowned by a simple stone watchtower and a low wooden palisade. A set of slippery earthen stairs leads down to the simple wooden bridge across the moat. A number of sharpened stakes at the bottom of the motte and hidden under the water of the moat are the only other defence of the small fort.

boardgame.name: Desert Dunes
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction

As far as the eye can see massive sand dunes stretch from one horizon to the other. As monotonous and unchanging the desert might look to the untrained eye, it is neither. The dunes are ever changing, slowly moving along as the wind moves them forward one grain of sand at a time. As it is now the chill of the night still lingers over the sand as the sun has just barely risen into the sky. While one side of the dunes is already bathed in the warming rays of the sun the other is still firmly in the dunes own shadows.

boardgame.name: Blankity-Blank!
boardgame.description:
Blankity-Blank! is a word game that will appeal to anyone who likes Scrabble, Boggle, Scattergories, and other word games. It's a family game designed for 2 to 6 players ages 12 and older.

To begin a round of Blankity-Blank!, you take a card from the box and let all the players see it. On the front of the card is an incomplete word with some letters left blank; for example, P--N-. You and every other player have three minutes to write down all the words you can think of that would complete that pattern, like phone or piano or plant or prank. When time is up you all read your lists aloud and cross out any word that more than one person wrote; you score points only for words that you alone thought of.

The front of the card indicates whether this is a 1-point, 2-point, or 3-point round, according to how many potential matches there are for this pattern. 1-point cards have dozens of possible solutions, 2-pointers not so many, and 3-point cards have the fewest of all. So you score 1, 2, or 3 points for each unique word in your list. (P--N- would be a 2-point card.)

When you've recorded the scores for this round, you may look at the back of the card. It shows a list of the most common words that would be correct solutions, so players can see some of the words no one thought of.

You continue to play with another card and another until one player has scored enough points to win. This can be 25 points, or 50, or any number the group agrees to.

The game includes over 500 cards, a pad of answer sheets, and a timer.

boardgame.name: Spell Effect Patterns: Cantrips & Orisons
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Ever wonder if your Sleep spell caught that last goblin but there was disagreement between you and a DM or player?

Ever experienced a stoppage in game play over an agonizing, time-consuming spell lookup in the Player's Handbook?

Get clearer results and faster answers by using Spell Effect Patterns (SEPs). These are an exciting new way for DMs and spellcasting players to 'see the results" of the spells characters cast, and to lessen lookup time in reference books.

Scaled for use with miniatures, these handy printouts answer the questions of "Who/what does my Burning Hands spell affect?", "What's the area of my Fireball?" and "How is my Detect Poison spell targetable?", among others. And they do it quickly, and in the coolest visual way possible (barring holographic explosions!!!)

Features:

Full-color, artistically-designed, and made for use with miniatures - cool!
Color-coded - each spell effect is outlined in a color which tells its school of magic - a handy mnemonic device.
Made to Scale -1 inch = 5 feet, the scale for almost all D&D; miniature campaigns.
Info-packed - Consult important spell information on the SEP while you use it!
Customizable - players can cut out the patterns to best utilize them during play
Durable - can be printed on cardstock and/or laminated for greater durability
Markable - If laminated, can be written on using dry- or wet-erase markers.
Spellbook Alternative - The patterns can be used as an alternative to a spellbook, and in most instances, referencing the Player's Handbook.
SEPs include patterns for different caster levels - for example, a Ray of Frost cast by a 1st level caster is 5 inches (25 feet range), whereas the same spell cast by a 2nd-3rd caster is 6 inches (range of 30 feet).
Each pattern has the full System Reference Document spell stat block and spell description included for your reference, and are in a block of text that can be cut and pasted to a 3?x5? card.

boardgame.name: Swish Jr.
boardgame.description:
Swish Jr. is a version for children of Swish, a pattern recognition card game in which players make matches – dubbed "Swishes" – before opponents.

Swish Jr. includes 42 transparent cards; each card has some combination of small shapes on it, with these items coming in four colors. To set up the game, lay out 12 cards on the table. Players simultaneously try to create "Swishes" by spotting two or more cards that can be laid on top of one another in some manner so that shapes of the same color fit. Create a Swish, and you claim the cards used, with new cards then being laid out. Whoever claims the most cards wins the game.

boardgame.name: Child Beauty Pageant Tycoon
boardgame.description: Child Beauty Pageant Tycoon is a game where you and your friends take the role of a mother whose greatest goal in life is to have her children win Beauty Pageants. The first player to win five Beauty Pageant crowns wins the game. There are 4 very different ways to make your Child ready to compete in a Pageant. 1) Spending a night with a Stud to give your child an edge from the very start. 2) Gaining experience by simply competing in Pageants. 3) Training your Child in a special Skill. 4) Buying a special 1-use Item to be used in any Pageant. Each Pageant will have different entry fees and winnings, and they will focus on different stats. When a pageant focuses on a stat, it counts for double towards winning the pageant. For example, let's say Mary Beth has a 'Smarts' score of 3. In the Pageant shown above, she will get to double her smarts score and it will instead give her 6 points toward winning the Pageant! Glitz or Talent stats still count toward winning, but they aren't doubled in this Pageant.

boardgame.name: Power Rangers Action Card Game
boardgame.description:
Players customize a deck of 30 cards depicting the heroes, villains, Zords, and Megazords of the Power Rangers universe. Cards are found in special starter sets, booster packs, and also packaged with Power Rangers toys from the 2013 line.

Turn Order:

1. Draw 2 cards.
2. Choose a Ranger or Villain to play, or pass. Discard cards equal to the play cost.
2. Optionally, players can summon Zords or Megazords if a Ranger was played in the previous step.
3. If only one player played a card, that card deals damage equal to its damage value twice.
4. If both players played a card, each player performs a "judgement" by rolling a die (or using an app or Morpher toy) to determine what power level their card fights at. The higher Power value wins. The loser is dealt damage equal to the winning card's damage value.
5. If the winner's card's rock/paper/scissors icon defeats the opponent's, the winner deals damage twice.
6. Damage is represented by moving cards from the draw deck into the discard pile.
7. The winner's card is discarded, the loser's is moved to the reinforcements area, where it can boost the "judgement" value in subsequent battles.
8. Play continues until one player runs out of cards in his or her draw deck. That player loses and the opponent wins!

boardgame.name: Critical Mass: Raijin vs Archon
boardgame.description:
Critical Mass is a fast-paced mech combat game. Players go head-to-head in this fighting-strategy game with deck-building aspects. Players choose their favorite mech to battle it out, with each mech offering a different loadout of cards to start the game and unique powers.

Each turn, players play a card face-down. When both players have chosen a card, they reveal them. Cards resolve based on their speed if they haven't been interrupted. Weapons deal damage and interrupt the enemy, while defending avoids weapon hits. Upgrading offers you additional cards to add to your arsenal but is vulnerable to being interrupted. Lastly, recharge reloads spent cards.

As cards are played, they go to their owner's cool-down pile, where they remain until they're reloaded. As players take damage, the armor on their mech is destroyed. When enough armor is destroyed, an armor core becomes vulnerable and can be destroyed to stun that mech for the next turn. The game ends when a mech's armor is completely destroyed down to the last core.

boardgame.name: Drummer Boy
boardgame.description:
This is a game for children with an American Civil War military theme published in 1890.

Players begin the game as a drummer boy and attempt to rise through the ranks and become a general. The board is styled like a maze and players move based on the results of a spinner.
Certain spaces on the board have special rules. A drum symbol allows the player to spin again. Other spaces have instructions like "Surly. Go to Guard House" and penalize the player.

The first child to reach the "General" space is declared he winner.

Includes a colorful 13" x 13" board illustrated with Civil War scenes, metal tokens, and a drum-shaped spinner.

boardgame.name: Future INC. High-Tech Stakes
boardgame.description:
Game designed by creative team Lans Macabre. It's an area control strategy based on resource use, betting and bluffing. Players take the roles of megacorporations’ CEOs to enlarge influence and dominance of the world. To do so they must spend resources to get control of cyberpunk freelancers - but it's not as easy as it sounds. The cyberpunks are very hard to control and everyone will try to recruit them. Each player will bet on different resources to get best results.
Future INC. is all about getting control over locations and gathering resources.
Each player starts with the same amount of skyscrapers and tries to expand by building new and capturing or destroying those belonging to other players. Thanks to skyscrapers players gain control over locations – areas of the cyberpunk world - and gather resources.

There are five types of resources in the game:
Credits - represent financial capabilities - used to build new skyscrapers.
Cybernetics - represent technological advancement - used to change ownership of enemy skyscrapers to yours.
Gear - represents military potential - used to destroy skyscrapers.
Programs- represent defense against "cyber terrorism" - used to counter enemy actions.
Influence - represents political power and intel – used to gain an advantage by manipulating game’s mechanics.

The most important thing in Future INC. is using free mercenaries - known as Cyberpunks - to do the dirty work. Using resources, corporation may influence a group of Cyberpunks to capture enemy building and gain victory points.

Game is divided into five turns, each has three phases:
1st phase, collecting resources: in which players gather resources, determine new targets for Cyberpunks and update points status.
2nd phase, mission: in which players, using bluff, bet on resources to gain control over the Cyberpunks.
3rd phase, actions of corporations: in which players spend resources to perform actions against each other.
Points are gathered by winning control over Cyberpunks and locations. The player with the highest score at the end of the fifth turn wins the game.

Future INC. High-Tech Stakes is a dynamic strategy for everyone who likes power struggle and a poker-like experience.

boardgame.name: 2000AD: Rogue Trooper Miniatures Game
boardgame.description:
By the same designer and publisher of the Judge Dredd Miniatures Game, 2000AD: Rogue Trooper Miniatures Game is a science-fiction skirmish 28mm miniatures wargame based (as the title suggests!) on the Rogue Trooper stories of the classic British comic, 2000AD.

A Kickstarter project started in February 2013, successfully funded within one day of launch, the intention is to publish a hardback rulebook and a range of miniatures for both sides, of the perpetual civil war on Nu-Earth. The Nort and Souther armies are asymmetrical (army lists are featured in the rulebook; units each have a base points cost and upgrades available for additional points).

The scope of the game is intended to be from a handful of miniatures (one GI vs. a Nort squad for example) up to company level actions, including light vehicles.

The range planned for release currently includes:
GI Rogue Trooper
Souther soldier squad set (8 figs)
Nort soldier squad set (8 figs)
Nort elite assault squad set (8 figs)
Nort & Souther officer squad set (6 figs)
Souther lazooker team squad set (6 figs)
Nort snipers and Black Dome sniper squad set (7 figs)
Skorpion Battlewagon (light tank, 3 variants planned)

Troops have their own basic statistics (points cost, movement, defence and armour values, morale (called Will-to-Fight; WtF in this game!), individual abilities (traits) etc. which are then augmented by the range and damage ratings of the weapon with which they are equipped (range, damage, traits). The more powerful a weapon is, the more combat dice rolled.

Rules cover ranged and close combat, remote weapons, indirect fire, elevation, suppression, air units, fighting from and in structures, etc.

Missions can be generated within the 'Engagement' chapter by combining various mission profiles (attack, defend, probe, hold, etc) to give an alternative to simple meeting engagements of equal cost forces. Success or failure is adjudicated by victory points specific to the various missions.

NB: This information is based upon the first release of the draft rulebook, and thus may be subject to change before release.

boardgame.name: TRAUMA Universalrollenspiel
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb

Von den weitläufigen Savannen der Urzeit mit ihren gigantischen Dinosauriern bis zu den unendlichen Tiefen des Weltalls einer hochtechnisierten Zukunft. Von der harten Realität historischer Schauplätze bis zu völlig freien Welten phantastischer Vorstellungen. Von den ernsthaftesten Szenarien bis zu den witzigsten Komödien. Wovon auch immer Ihre Träume handeln mögen, in TRAUMA steckt alles drin. Das Grundregelwerk umfasst nicht nur die Grundregeln für abwechslungsreiches Rollenspiel in allen erdenklichen Genres, es beinhaltet auch die Charaktererschaffung, hunderte von Fertigkeiten aller Epochen, umfangreiche Kampf- und Medizinregeln, Magie und Zaubersprüche, eine Anleitung zur Erschaffung eigener Spielwelten, zahlreiche Kreaturen, Hinweise für Spielleiter sowie einigeBeispielcharaktere. TRAUMA ist für neue Spieler genauso geeignet wie für alte Hasen.

Publisher blurb (user translation)

From the sweeping savannas of primordial times with it's gigantic dinosaurs to infinite depths of space in a hi-tech future. From the harsh reality of historical settings to worlds of unbound, phantastic imaginations. From serious scenarios to the funniest comedies. Whatever you are dreaming of, TRAUMA has it. The core book not only includes rules for diverse role-playing experiences in any genre you can think of, but also character creation rules, hundreds of skills of all epochs, combat and healing rules, magic and spells, a guide to worldbuilding, many creatures, GM tips and sample characters. TRAUMA is suited for new as well as experienced players.

User summary
According to the author, TRAUMA is based on the Rune Quest system. In late 2012, a second, revised edition was announced.

boardgame.name: The Book of Shadow Bindings
boardgame.description:
From the website (no longer online)

Shadow Bindings is a roleplaying mechanics system, that is meant to be a more flexible system than Fantasy Realms, with less reliance on modifying the character construction system to suit particular worldbases. It is also intended to better represent realism in combat situations than Fantasy Realms did, and to deal with those areas of genre that Fantasy Realms cannot cover currently because of its simplex structure.

Shadow Bindings takes the best elements of the Fantasy Realms mechanic, plus those of some of our previous work with the Mystic Earth RPG and some new ideas towards streamlining some parts of game play. It is designed in such a way that worlds, scenarios etc developed for it will also be usable by those who prefer the Fantasy Realms mechanics.

Shadow Bindings is a Free-To-Use Roleplaying game. This means you can use it as a basis for any game you run, are welcome to adapt it, share copies of it with your friends, print it out to paper or do anything else you want with it, except sell it for a profit.

boardgame.name: Nornis: Fantasy-Abenteuerrollenspiel in der Welt Aveon
boardgame.description:
Publisher blurb

NORNIS ist ein Fantasy-Abenteuerrollenspiel auf der Welt Aveon. Das Grundregelwerk beinhaltet eine ausführliche Beschreibung des Weltenhintergrundes, sowie das Regelsystem und damit alles, was man braucht, um in eine fantastische Welt voller Mythen, alter Geschichten und Legenden einzutauchen. Die Regeln sind leicht verständlich und unterstützen das Storytelling - Konzept von NORNIS. Das Spiel basiert auf einem 12seitigen Würfel. Neben dem Grundsystem helfen mehr als zwanzig Optionalregeln. In der Welt Aveon schlüpfen Sie in die Rolle unterschiedlicher Zwerge, Menschen und Elfen und erleben Ihr eigenes Abenteuer auf der Suche nach verschollenen Artefakten oder beim Aufdecken von Intrigen in einer Welt voller Zauberei und Fantasie.

translation
NORNIS is a fantasy adventure role-playing game in the world Aveon. The rulebook includes a detailed setting description and the rules - thus everything you need to immerse yourself in a fantastic world full of myths, ancient stories and legends. The rules are easy to understand and support the storytelling concept of NORNIS. The game is based on a d12. Besides the core system you will find more than twenty optional rules. In the world Aveon you take on the role of different dwarves, humans and elves and enjoy your own adventure in search of lost artifacts or in the detection of intrigue in a world of magic and fantasy.

boardgame.name: Dangerous Dave's Risky Rescue
boardgame.description:
Dangerous Dave's Risky Rescue (known informally as Dangerous Dave 3) is a platform game developed by Gamer's Edge and published by Softdisk in 1993 for DOS computers. It is the sequel to Dangerous Dave in the Haunted Mansion, and is also the first Dangerous Dave game to not be programmed by John Romero. This is because he, John Carmack, Adrian Carmack and Tom Hall had left Softdisk by this point to form id Software. It was followed by a sequel, Dave Goes Nutz!, which shares similar gameplay elements.

Like the previous title, Dangerous Dave is on a mission to save his little brother Delbert, this time from the evil "Dr. Nemesis" (who is also the main antagonist in Softdisk's Catacomb franchise).

Source: Wikipedia, "Dangerous Dave's Risky Rescue", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Bank-Letterspel
boardgame.description:
Promotional game for the Dutch bank Raiffeisenbank and this is The Bank Letter Game.

Simple crossword card game, similar to games like Lexicon and Kan-U-Go. In your turn you may play a maximum of 4 cards. Words must be formed that use at least one letter of an existing word (except for the first word obviously which, incidentally, must be a four letter word). Any word can be extended though, if possible. Game includes two Jokers which have an image of an old motor car.

The first player to use all his cards wins the round. The other players total the values of their unused cards and the winner of the round scores a total of all those points (each card has a number value on it).

The winner of the game is the first player to reach a pre-agreed score.

The backs of the cards are quite novel. They can be used to make four different jigsaws. It is suggested that 6 to 8 year olds might like to do the jigsaws. I doubt it, they are extremely difficult for their size.

boardgame.name: The Savage World of My Little Pony (4th Edition)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

You who are about to game, I salute you!

This 4th Edition of The Savage World of My Little Pony is the culmination of over a year and half of work, both by myself and by the numerous others who contributed to its continuing evolution since its conception in early February of 2011. It is my labor of love and gift to the greater My Little Pony fandom at large, and I am sure that you will be able to see the amount of exacting detail and work that has been put into making it as complete as possible. I hope that it inspires others to use their own skills and create something that they can then bring to others and share in the sense of community that this game has created for me.

[…]

The Savage Worlds system is designed to be Fast, Furious, and Fun; a perfect game for new and experienced players alike. Few games offer this combination of streamlined simplicity and simultaneous complexity, and is a perfect way to introduce people into the world of roleplaying games.

The fact that you are reading this means that it is likely you are a fan of, or at least aware of, the show My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic and are interested in the unique things that it’s universe has to offer the roleplayer. I have conceived this system as a means to play almost any sort of story in the Friendship is Magic universe that one might think of, from episodic slice-of-life stories to grand epics that see the players match wits with terrifying foes and daunting challenges. The only limit is your own imagination.

Black Crusade
The Tome of Excess
Embrace your desires and surrender to sensation!

Slaanesh is the Chaos God of Pleasure and Excess. He offers the limitless bliss of endless passions and insatiable appetites to his legions of depraved followers.

This book introduces four new Heretic Archetypes, along with cruel weapons, rules for empowering minions, new Daemon Engines, and more to amplify the rapacious hordes of the Dark Prince.

Rules for expanded interactions and social combat allow players of all alignments to seduce their foes into becoming devoted lackeys. They also gaining new ways to use their growing Infamy, plus new dark rituals to curse and entrap enemies.

boardgame.name: Turf Wars
boardgame.description:
Turf Wars is a game of conquest. Players are encouraged to form alliances and manipulate the situation so that ultimately, your faction, and preferably your faction alone, dominates the land.

There are up to ten (10) rounds of game play for Turf Wars each of which consists of five (5) phases:
• Perform Pre-Event Action(s)
• Place Reinforcement Troops
• Reveal Event
• Select Action Cards and Perform Actions
• Score & Spend Dominance Points

Object of the Game
There are four (4) ways your faction can win:
1. Dominate the appropriate number of turfs on the board that match your faction’s Home Turf.
2. Land the killing blow while wiping out your faction’s nemesis, if in play.
3. Achieve the objective outlined on any of your Secret Win Cards.
4. Attain highest number of Dominance Points (DP)at the end of 10 rounds. This results in a win only if no other win conditions are met first.

This is a Japanese science fiction wargame set in the universe of the Legend of the Galactic Heroes. This set covering the Sirius Campaign, was the early age battles before main story.

Two scenarios are contained in the game, and the fictional space battle that each was drawn in the story is reproduced. These are being called a fleet battle, but when either is said, it is close to the land battle of Napoleonic age.

The winner determined by the number which made a fleet collapse. A fleet collapses when a fixed unit is eliminate or admiral's mental agitation.

boardgame.name: Fox & Rabbits
boardgame.description:
Cheeky rabbits race around the field, hiding behind bushes to outwit the sharp-eyed fox.

A roll and move, players choose three rabbits of the same colour and place them on one corner of the field on the START hole.

1. The starting player throws the dice and does two things in the following order:
a)Moves the fox to the sector of the centre circle corresponding to the number,
b)Moves one of his Rabbits in a clockwise direction on the track.

E.G. If a 2 were thrown, the player first moves the Fox onto sector 2; secondly, he moves one of his rabbits two places in a clockwise direction.

2. If the fox can "see" any rabbits in that sector of the board, they must go back to their START hole.

3. If a rabbit is in the same sector as the fox BUT is behind a bush, then it is hidden from view and does not go back to START.

4. Play moves in a clockwise direction.

5. On their first three turns, each player must bring out all three of their rabbits. If a rabbit is sent back to his START hole, it must be brought out onto the track on the player's next turn.

6. Any number of Rabbits may occupy the same space on the track.

7. If a six is thrown the player may have an extra turn.

8. A player does not have to throw the exact number to get a rabbit HOME.

The same rules apply for a two or three player game.

boardgame.name: Annihilation
boardgame.description:
Annihilation is a Battleship-style game for two players using pencil and paper. Each player receives an identical printed sheet from a game pad, featuring a circular overhead map of the northern hemisphere. The map is divided into boxes by longitudinal and latitudinal lines, which are labeled by numbers and by names of constellations. Some boxes are shaded, representing the oceans. Also present are boxes to track each player’s hits; in place of ships are (in order of most to least boxes) Capital, Trade and Industry, Air Base, Navy, and Peace. Each player “hides” each of these objectives on his own side of the map, vertically, horizontally, or diagonally. The Navy must be in the ocean, Peace is a single box that may be anywhere, and the rest must be on land.

Each player then takes a turn firing volleys at the other side. A volley consists of 15 bombs, which can be any combination of airplane bombs, rockets, or atomics. Airplane bombs count for 1 bomb against the limit, rockets for 3, atomics for 5. Volleys are done all at once, with the opponent not announcing hits until the volley is over. Players track these developments by crossing off boxes on their paper. When a player sends a volley, if he has previously received any hits, those hits are subtracted from the 15 bombs he may fire on his current turn.

Airplane bombs strike only the square called by the player, rockets strike the first square and any two adjoining squares called immediately by the player, and atomics strike the initial square as well as the four adjoining squares along all four sides. Any target hit on one square by an atomic is immediately destroyed, any target hit by a rocket suffers an additional box hit after what the player targeted. Should any player strike the target of Peace, the game is immediately over, otherwise the game is won when all of a player’s other targets are destroyed.

boardgame.name: Guile
boardgame.description:
Guile is a medieval memory card game of deception and intrigue for two players. Players are either the noble King Arthur or the nefarious Sir Mordred, and the Knights of the Round Table are the instruments of your influence in Camelot. Your chosen knights will advance your schemes as you trace the web of subterfuge and manipulate it to your own ends. The victor will wield the most influence when each Knight's loyalties are revealed.

The Round Table is formed by eight face-up Knights, with each player controlling four. Each Knight also bears a face-down Influence Card on top of it. On his turn, a player can look at the Influence Card of his Knight-errant or exchange that card with an Influence Card of any other Knight at the Round Table. Play continues in this manner until the turns have circled the Round Table twice. At that time, all of the face-down Influence cards are revealed, and the player who has the highest sum of Influence wins the round. A new round is set up and played again, and the first person to win two rounds wins the game.

Who will hold sway in Camelot? And who will hold sway on the morrow? Only time will tell...

Guile includes the 'inspansion' "Extended Cast", which adds even more possibilities for treachery and deceit.

boardgame.name: Pipword
boardgame.description:
Each card has both a letter and one face of a standard die. Before each turn, 5 dice are rolled and placed on the dice board in order of their colors. Then the player tries to play a word of 3-5 letters, whose die faces match a contiguous subset of the dice on the board. If they do, they score the sum of the cards' pips, doubled for 4-letter words and tripled for 5-letter words. There are also wild cards, and slug cards that can be added at either end.

The winner is the first person to reach the specified total score, e.g. 100 for 4-5 players.

From the web page:
" Cool Factors:

Easy to carry.
Quick to learn and play.
Fun for word-lovers and strategy gamers alike.

Description:
Shuffle the custom deck and deal each player ten cards. Select a card from your hand to keep and pass the rest to your neighbor. Keep cherry-picking a single card from each hand until they're depleted. Each player then tries to make a single word from his cards. Letters you use in your word score points--cards you take but don't use count against you! Be the first to score 100 points, and you've won.

It has a deck of 60 cards, which have a letter and number, in different colors. Rarer letters like J and Q have multipliers on them, and there are wild cards.

boardgame.name: Oh My Word
boardgame.description:
From the web site:
" Cool Factors:

Amazing 12+ Games in one!
Fast, stimulating game play!
Fun for the whole family - always fresh!

Description:
“Oh My Word” is not just one game, but is 12+ games in one, with more being developed and added frequently! You can play any of the games with the same deck of cards!

One of the most fun and exciting games ever created is “Battle of Words!” It comes in “quick start,” "basic," and "advanced" versions. The basic version can be mastered in a matter of minutes and is fun for the entire family. The play consists of forming words, lengthening existing words, combining words, and stealing words from your opponent(s). The advanced version is easy to learn but will stimulate and challenge even the most astute word gamers. In addition to the basic play, there are 20 action cards that create all kinds of excitement and dynamics between the players. In either version, each player competes for high score through word values, word length values, bonus letter values, bonus word values, other word bonuses, and the number / quality of words acquired by the end of the game.

You can also play the following;
“Cross Words” - plays similar to a crossword puzzle game, without the limits of a regular game.
“Play On Words” - plays similar to a 3-D crossword puzzle game, without standard limitations.
“Finding the Right Words” - plays similar to a cubed word game, without the grid or cube.
“The Last Word” - plays similar to a word jumble or word search, with strategy & scoring options.
“Simple Words” - plays similar to solitaire, but played with words and is more entertaining.

You can even play poker style games that involve many more strategies and scoring options, such as;
“Word For Word” - plays similar to Texas Hold 'em.
“Keep Your Word” - plays similar to 7-Card Stud.
“Choose Your Words” - plays similar to 7-Card Draw.
“Hold Your Words” - plays similar to 7-Card No Draw.
“A Few Words” - plays similar to 7-Card No Peek.

In addition, you get "Your Words, Not Mine" which creates several more variations of game play, allowing you to play many of the games backwards! Rather than competing for high score, each player competes for low score by transferring their words / scores to other players."

The deck comes with 176 cards.

boardgame.name: The Calixis Sector Encyclopedia
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

When Black Industries published Dark Heresy, they openly requested fans to submit descriptions of planets. Various of the submissions they received were edited and used to expand the newly-created Calixis Sector, becoming an official part of the game's setting. The core rulebook of course had limited space, so the full descriptions for all the planets that Black Industries accepted were published on the company's website, forming a freely-accessible gazetteer of the Calixis Sector.

Following Games Workshop's closure of the Black Industries imprint, Fantasy Flight Games acquired the licence to publish role-playing games set in the Warhammer Fantasy and Warhammer 40,000 universes. They retained an on-line gazetteer for the Calixis Sector, but in a cut-down form that detailed only the major worlds.

But fans had saved copies of the full original content and compiled it into a PDF titled "The Calixis Sector Encyclopedia". This PDF can still be found, circulated by fans on various internet forums dedicated to discussing Dark Heresy and related games.

Our Terms and Conditions
1. General
All transactions between Gamers HQ and you, the customer, are subject to the following conditions, which you acknowledge by accepting delivery of your ordered products. These conditions do not affect your statutory rights and in all cases German law applies.
2. Orders and prices
We do our level best to ensure that the information on our website is up-to-date. Please note that offers and prices are subject to change. We work to ensure that our prices are all correct, but cannot be held responsible for accidentally displaying the wrong price of a product.
All prices are quoted in Euros and already include all necessary taxes.
3. Lead times and delivery costs
Our products are delivered directly from our Berlin base, and orders are usually dispatched within two working days. Dispatch and transport are at the expense of the customer. We usually ship orders with DHL but explicitly reserve the right to choose another method of transport. If an order is split into several deliveries, each delivery counts as a separate transaction.
Delivery within Germany is free of charge if your order amounts to a total of 50 euros or more. Below that amount, we charge a one-off fee of 5 euros.
Our products can also be ordered for delivery outside Germany. In that case, an estimate of the delivery costs is added to your order during checkout. Please note that this delivery cost estimate does not necessarily constitute the final amount. We shall contact you personally by email after you have placed your order to present you with delivery options and to quote the final price for delivery costs.
4. Payment options
We currently offer the following three payment options: direct debit from your bank account (only within Germany), bank transfer (prepayment) and PayPal. Once you have placed three orders, we also offer you the option to pay by invoice. Such privileges can, however, be withdrawn should we encounter repeated delays in settling invoices.
5. Cancellations, Refunds & Returns Should you wish to cancel your order, you can do so by notifying us by fax, email, letter or by simply returning your product(s) to Gamers HQ. No questions asked. Please note that such a cancellation has to be done within two weeks after having received your ordered product(s). Should you have already paid for your order, we shall refund those costs to you as soon as we have received your cancellation notification. Please ensure that any products returned are in good condition. If you check the products in a manner that you will have done, for example, in a shop, this is fine. Any other handling of the product(s) might entitle Gamers HQ to some compensation from you, which might in rare cases amount to the original sum paid for the product(s). So should you feel that you might cancel your order by returning the products, please limit your inspection of the products to optical checks and do not use them on a regular basis. If you return your order within two weeks in the above manner, we shall refund you the costs for sending the product(s) back to us (unless your cancelled order amounts less than 20 euros, in which case you as the customer will bear the cost of return postage). Please ensure that you use appropriate packing material when sending back the product(s) — preferably using the original wrapping. Please note that German law, following the EU directive 97/7/EG of 20 May 1997, specifies that the right to return items and receive a full refund is not applicable to the purchase of newspapers, magazines or journals (§312d BGB) as well as the purchase of audio- or video-recordings and software once you have broken the seal of the package. Should we accidently send you the wrong products, please return them to us and we shall refund you the return postage immediately. Any cancellation of an order has to be done in writing (by post, fax or email). 6. Ownership
Please note that ordered products remain our property until you have fully paid for them.
7. Personal data
We are committed to protecting your personal information and will keep the information you entrust to us safely and securely. We may collect information from you to monitor website visitor patterns, so that we can improve our website. We also collect information from you to handle orders, deliver products and services, process payments, communicate with you about orders, products and services, update our records and generally maintain your customer profile with us. However, we shall never sell or share your personal information with third parties. Our customer data — in so far as required to provide the above services and within the limits defined by the data protection laws of Germany (paragraph 26 BDSG) — is saved and handled on a separate, network-independent computer.
8. Other matters
We reserve the right to reject orders without any explanation. Also please note that you as a customer cannot assert a claim against Gamers HQ if, for whatever reason, we are unable to source the item(s) you have ordered. Such cases arise only very exceptionally; we try to ensure that everything we advertise in our web shop is in stock. Where, for whatever reason, we are unable to deliver we promptly refund in full everything you have paid.
9. Limitation of liability: external links
Although we check the content of external links provided on our website, we have no control over or responsibility for these domains to which we provide the links or which link to us. That responsibility solely rests with those who manage the respective domains.
10. Place of jurisdiction
Any disputes arising hereunder will be settled before a Berlin court. We reserve the right to choose the customer's place of jurisdiction instead.
11. Severability clause
If parts of these terms and conditions become ineffective, the remainder of these terms still apply.

boardgame.name: Hordes: High Command
boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Brutal conflict spreads across the wilds of western Immoren, fought by savage warriors and terrible beasts. Powerful warlords orchestrate grand strategies and daring battlefield tactics, their actions bringing glorious victory — or the despair of final defeat. Do you have the courage and cunning to guide your forces to ultimate triumph? Take command of the mightiest warriors and beasts to conquer the wilds of Immoren!

In Hordes: High Command, each player takes control of one faction of the Hordes world – Skorn, Circle of Orboros, Trollblods or Legion of Eveblight – leading whole armies of soldiers, Warlocks and mighty Warbeasts to great battles which will shake all of Immoren and change it forever. Each faction has individual decks with faction-specific warbeasts, units, and resources which assure different strategy and gameplay from the other factions. Additionally, before each game, players choose three of the five warlocks specific to their faction. This decision makes every game different and allows for multiple strategies. During the game, players play a whole season of War, trying to build up their strength, then capture strategic locations to earn victory points.

Hordes: High Command can be combined with the following other core sets:

designer summary

After three editions of Warhammer fantasy role play game, three different editions of Dwarf supplements (they have even a magazine called White Dwarf), and no Elf supplement at all; in these times where we are working to correct gender discrimination, I decided to work to correct race discrimination!

In this fan project you will find the recompilation of the recent history of the Asur and some of their most fabled heroes, descriptions of the different regions of Ulthuan and house rules for regional features of the Asur, Elven culture and religion, a short description of Elftown -the largest high elf settlement in the land of men, house rules for High Elf nobles in the harsh Empire lands, and the role of high magic in the Asur every-day life as well as house rules for High Magic apprenticeship.

boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The battles of Warhammer: Invasion grow larger and more intense than ever before with the multiplayer battles of Cataclysm, the game's fourth deluxe expansion. Cataclysm comes with a rulebook, six fulcrum cards, 38 tokens, and 159 player cards (three copies each of fifty-three different cards) that allow up to four players to war for dominion over the Old World.

The expansion also provides new ammunition for those who wish to continue exploring the fast-paced, bloody, back-and-forth battles of the two-player matches from the Warhammer: Invasion - The Card Game Core Set.

The Cataclysm multiplayer format builds upon the game's classic kingdom building, questing, and battles, but follows rules for a new turn sequence that explores the shifting tides of battle between the Old World’s six main races. Meanwhile, you'll war to acquire as many copies as they can of a new form of token – the dominance token, which represents the success of your efforts to subdue your foes and establish your rule.

boardgame.name: Darklands
boardgame.description:
Darklands is a world in which you command the armies of man and beast that your ancestors once did for glory, power or simple survival.

What if dragons really flew and giants really walked the earth? What if berserkers actually were bear-men, man and bear joined together? What if all of the myths and legends we take for granted were real and our ancestors fought against - and with - creatures and beings and realms we thought were nothing more than the fantasies of our uncivilised selves?

Based in the Dark Ages in the year 650AD in Northwest Europe, Darklands is a Skirmish Wargame that allows you to field the men and mythological beasts of the time. This game will allow you to:
- Take command of Norse Trolls and Jötunn and conduct raids on the coast of Dark Age Britain.
- Lead the hosts of Baalor, the Evil Eye in the Ice, and the Fomoraic, a race of half men and beast along with hideous sea creatures under the thrall of Baalor in their quest to crush Dark Age Ireland.
- Defend Dark Age Wales with the Brythoniaid and their draconic allies.

The game will feature the following Kindreds (factions):
- Albainn (Picts)
- Angelcynn (Angles)
- Atalantes (Classic Greeks from the mythical continent of Atlantis)
- Brythoniaid (Welsh Britons)
- Byzantii (Dark Age Romans)
- Érainn (Irish)
- Fomoraic (Fomorians)
- Khthones (Escaped slaves of the Atlantes and all are Reptilian Anthropomorphs such as Snakes, Crocodiles, Hydras and Basilisks)
- Norse (Vikings)
- Ysians (An alliance of Kernow and the mythical city of Ys)

With these additional, smaller Kindreds appearing as allies to the others:
- The Vras (Greedy ratmen allied with the Ysians)
- Infernii (Daemons from Dantes Divine Comedy allied with the Byzantii)

Some features of the gameplay:
- Individual alternate unit activation
- D10s based
- Inches are the primary measurement
- Game turns are called 'Hours'
- Will feature weather and time of day
- A big mechanic of the game is that all warriors large and small, when they are wounded, become weaker for the rest of the game.
- Bows will be able to shoot arrows the length of the table and beyond - but their shots loose power with increased range.
- Army Standards and Army Musicians important to game play and orders
- Plastic round bases with arcs of visibility pre-marked
- Dark Magic will be involved. Using it will come “at a price”

boardgame.name: Space Marauder
boardgame.description:
Space Marauder is a scrolling shooter, and has been compared to NES and SNES era shooter games such as Space Megaforce. The game puts the player in the role an infantryman dropped into an alien base that is determined to enslave humanity. There are three different power-ups, and the game allows you to shoot in eight different directions. However, due to the difficulty of switching the direction of fire during the midst of battle, it is regarded to be easier to just shoot in one direction. The three power-ups are considered standard for the genre: a blue bullet, a lighter blue laser, and a pink laser. The game uses a password system to continue progress.

Source: Wikipedia, "Space Marauder", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Night Eternal: A True Blood Card Game
Night Eternal: The Game
boardgame.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In ancient times, immortal vampires played games with people's lives and with real blood stakes. Now in card game form, no real blood will be spilled, but the strategy, tactics, and power-plays still abound. Based upon a game that exists in the True Blood universe, Night Eternal: The Game is a competitive card game of intrigue, power-plays and betrayal where vampires jockey for power, position and ultimate control of the rival factions: The Authority and The Monarchy.

Players must ante blood from their pools to both factions each turn of the game. Players build up their hands by acquiring cards from a powerful, but temperamental Immortals deck and a willing and able Agent deck. The cards that a player chooses to play will determine the faction to which he or she is loyal...for now. In turn order, each player plays out one card (face up) during each of three rounds each turn, so you never just how much power it will take to seize control of a faction each turn.

Players must pay attention to the cards their opponents are playing. It's more difficult to enable a powerful card's special ability if your opponents are playing weaker cards. Weaker card special abilities are easy to resolve, but weakness doesn't win the war. Special abilities might allow a player to steal blood from a faction or move it from one faction to another, so switching your loyalty to a new faction (by playing cards of that faction) might just throw off your opponents' best laid plans.

In the end, power still rules the day. At the end of each turn (after three rounds of card play), the cards are scored. The player with the highest value of Authority cards earns that faction's blood pool. The player with the highest value of Monarchy cards earns that faction's blood pool. The key to victory is to have more blood tokens than any other player when the first player dies...by running out
of blood.

Players each have one or two pawns. Depending on a dice roll they chose which pawn to advance along the spiral. User Summary

Less a vast MMO proper than a series of instanced Beat 'em Up levels connected by a town, DFO features typical RPG classes like Mage, Fighter, Thief, and Priest, as well as "Gunner" and "Slayer". The whole game is 2D, in SNES style, and combat plays very much like a Final-Fight-type beat-'em-up. The variety of special moves -- all skills, which you purchase and improve with skill points gained from levelling up -- are mostly launched using arrow key combinations with the main two attack buttons, a la Street Fighter.

boardgame.name: The Quiet Year
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:

For a long time, we were at war with The Jackals. But now, we’ve driven them off, and we have this – a year of relative peace. One quiet year, with which to build our community up and learn once again how to work together. Come Winter, the Frost Shepherds will arrive and we might not survive beyond that. But we don’t know about that yet. What we know is that right now, in this moment, there is an opportunity to build something.

The Quiet Year is a map game. You define the struggles of a post-apocalyptic community, and attempt to build something good within their quiet year. Every decision and every action is set against a backdrop of dwindling time and rising concern.

The game is played using a deck of cards – each of the 52 cards corresponds to a week during the quiet year. Each card triggers certain events – bringing bad news, good omens, project delays and sudden changes in luck. At the end of the quiet year, the Frost Shepherds will come, ending the game.

boardgame.name: Exodus: The Trading Card Game
boardgame.description:
The Exodus TCG is an extremely fast-paced card game, designed to play in an average of 5-10 minutes suitable for all ages and skill levels. It's the first trading card game in the world to feature mechanics that affect card rarity! There's no banlist, no rotation, and no reprints from set-to-set. Expansions offer new and interesting mechanics and themes without relying on power-creep.

A mass Exodus to the newborn planet Eeventide is occurring. As you venture from Earth to Eeventide, you become a Drifter, gaining the ability to fly and drift across a new world. Forge a special deck of cards from stardust, and battle other Drifters by summoning massive creatures to fight for you! Your very existence is bound to the planet by a mysterious contraption that glows with an ethereal light. You can join a faction or fight solo as you pave a path.

The first three guilds have risen, Dragonis, Skyborn & the Order, each fighting over a planet that requires constant conflict in order to remain stable.


Players begin the game with 10 Life Points, which represent their will to battle. Each player takes turns playing by following the 5 Phases of a Turn:

Draw Phase: Draw 3 cards from your Energy Deck and 3 cards from your Main Deck
Energy Phase: Play your energy onto the field by stacking them into piles in any arrangement you'd like (maximum 3-energy per pile by default)
Creature Phase: Summon as many creatures from your hand as you'd like by placing them on blank piles of energy
Attack Phase: Attack your opponent's creatures using your own, or attack their Life Points directly if they have no creatures
End Phase: Pass the turn to your opponent



Players win the game by using their creatures to attack their opponent's Life Points directly. Each energy behind a creature counts as 1 point of damage in a direct attack. Players can attack with as many creatures as they want during their turn, and use instant-speed Symmetry cards to make their creatures stronger or to drastically change circumstances during a duel. Symmetry cards are like quick-play instants that can be played literally at any time to interrupt gameplay (they can be used on your turn or your opponent's turn, on any phase)!

Energy cards are universal in function, so players can use any combination of cards. Decks can be constructed by following the one simple rule of limiting 2 copies of a card per deck (excluding energy).


(Set 1) Birth of Creation Harmonized Dragonis & Skyborn Starter Decks (Unlimited Edition) are now available, Premiere Edition is sold out,
(Set 2) Galaxy Tides (First Edition) Boosters are now available,
(Set 3) Crystal Forge Treeforge & Shardveil Competitive Decks (First Edition) are now available, released August 2017,

boardgame.name: The Bombardment of Alexandria 1882
boardgame.description:
From the Rules

The Bombardment of Alexandria 1882 is an additional historical scenario for use with BoneGames game of late 19th century warfare Queen Victoria's Navy. This scenario is not a complete game. Ownership of Queen Victoria's Navy (and the Admiral on Deck expansion) is necessary in order to use this scenario. Visit the BoneGames website at www.bonegames.com for information about Queen Victoria's Navy, Admiral on Deck, and other games by BoneGames.

Historical Background

Early in 1882 the Egyptian Army forced the Khedive, Tewfik Pasha, to appoint Colonel Said Ahmed Arabi AKA Arabi Pasha as the new Minister of War. In this position, and with the backing of the army, Arabi was the de facto ruler of the country. Arabi was viewed with distrust in both Britain and France. This distrust was not without reason as he and his followers viewed the Khedive as a puppet of the Europeans, attacked Europeans in the streets, and threatened to nationalize the Suez Canal leaving the stockholders without a cent, and to repudiate Egypt's foreign loans.

A combination of fear for the Canal, the shortest route to India after all, the outraged cries of the investors and a pinch of concern for the Europeans in Egypt, plus a heavy dose of Jingoism led the British government to prepare for war. France, for some very convoluted internal political reasons, reversed policy and refused to help.

While an Army was being assembled the British decided that their first step should be to neutralize the extensive coastal batteries defending Alexandria. On 10 July,Vice Admiral Sir B. P. Seymour demanded that the forts, then being strengthened, be surrendered. The navies of other nations and all commercial shipping quickly sailed out of port. The Egyptians refused this demand and Queen Victoria’s Navy cleared for action. On 11 July, 1882 the bombardment began at 0650 hours.

boardgame.name: Signature Bingo
boardgame.description:
User Summary

In Signature Bingo players work to create a 'bingo' by finding people to sign their bingo card. Each square on the bingo card has a phrase or statement that must apply to the person being asked; for example, a player might be searching for someone who fits the square, "I can speak 2 languages," and thus ask a new acquaintance whether they can or not. If the acquaintance can, the player asks for their signature on the square.
Players who achieve Bingo within a particular time frame are usually rewarded with a prize, though the game is more of an ice-breaker for large groups.

boardgame.name: Pirates!
boardgame.description:
From the designer's website:

This is a game for incredible adventures, fun and relaxing, very undemanding, a game well suited for improvisation. You play a pirate, vile, dirty, unfair, disrespectful and cruel, wandering the Caribbean in search of treasure, alcohol and beautiful women. Pirates do not have an ounce of reflection and throw themselves headlong into the adventure, taking all the risks, regularly receiving memorable blows that would kill an average whale but which merely slow down the pirates. They are superstitious and have a kind of moral code of their own which is usually the cause of crazy situations.

This is a game for those who know nothing about navigation, sailing, geography in the seventeenth century nor anything too serious. There is no real immersion, just the "color" and laughing. Think of it as a pirate movie who will not teach you anything, but will give you a good time. Thanks to the rules, the GM has very little work and will mostly give story primers and hit back the PCs, the game will move on its own. The rules also encourage players to play together, not against each other.

The topic require some maturity, after all it is a question of murder, teasing ladies, drinking, rapine... This is a light and fun caricature of a world which in reality was much darker. Here beatings given or received have little importance, there is no display of blood or guts, just the infantile "bam! you're dead" and "bing! in your teeth." You must also learn to accept the frequent disappointments that your character will suffer.

Pirates! differs from other games on the same theme by the extreme simplicity of the rules, the rather low preparation involved and the tone which is light hearted rather than epic.

boardgame.name: Actual Sunlight
boardgame.description:
Actual Sunlight is a short interactive story about love, depression and the corporation.

The game puts you in the role of Evan Winter, a young professional in Toronto, as he moves through three distinct periods of his life. The story is linear, unavoidable and (hopefully) thought-provoking. You experience his perceptions, fall under the consequences of his decisions, and meet everyone who didn’t change him.

Gameplay is minimal, and serves only to move from one part of the (admittedly) text-heavy story to the next. The game fiercely attempts to be worth it.

Actual Sunlight is not appropriate for children. It features mature themes and an adult-workplace amount of profanity. And it does so immediately.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.name: Firefly: Das Spiel
Firefly: El Juego
Firefly: The Game
boardgame.description:
Players begin with a ship, and travel from planet to planet, hiring crew, purchasing ship upgrades, and picking up cargo to deliver (jobs) all in the form of cards. Some crew and cargo are illegal, and can be confiscated if your ship is boarded by an alliance vessel. Travelling from planet to planet requires turning over "full burn" cards, one for each space moved. Most do nothing, but you can also encounter an Alliance ship, have a breakdown, or even run into Reavers. Completing jobs gets you cash. First player to complete the story goals wins.

Game description from the publisher:

In Firefly: The Game – based on the popular Firefly television series created by Joss Whedon – players captain their own Firefly-class transport ship, traveling the 'Verse with a handpicked crew of fighters, mechanics and other travelers. As a captain desperate for work, players are compelled to take on any job — so long as it pays. Double-dealing employers, heavy-handed Alliance patrols, and marauding Reavers are all in a day's work for a ship's captain at the edge of the 'Verse. Firefly: The Game is a high-end thematic tabletop boardgame from Gale Force Nine (GF9) and the first in a series of tabletop hobby board games and miniatures games from GF9 set in the Firefly Universe.

Description Players begin with a ship, and travel from planet to planet, hiring crew, purchasing ship upgrades, and picking up cargo to deliver (jobs) all in the form of cards. Some crew and cargo are illegal, and can be confiscated if your ship is boarded by an alliance vessel. Travelling from planet to planet requires turning over "full burn" cards, one for each space moved. Most do nothing, but you can also encounter an Alliance ship, have a breakdown, or even run into Reavers. Completing jobs gets you cash. First player to complete the story goals wins. Game description from the publisher:
In Firefly: The Game – based on the popular Firefly television series created by Joss Whedon – players captain their own Firefly-class transport ship, traveling the 'Verse with a handpicked crew of fighters, mechanics and other travelers. As a captain desperate for work, players are compelled to take on any job — so long as it pays. Double-dealing employers, heavy-handed Alliance patrols, and marauding Reavers are all in a day's work for a ship's captain at the edge of the 'Verse. Firefly: The Game is a high-end thematic tabletop boardgame from Gale Force Nine (GF9) and the first in a series of tabletop hobby board games and miniatures games from GF9 set in the Firefly Universe.

boardgame.name: Konsorcjum
boardgame.description:
Consortium is a print & play dice game for 1 to 6 persons in which the players take the roles of powerful businessmen, trying to acquire the most worthy concessions possible. The concessions concern three types of natural resources (energetic resources (E), metals (M) and water (W)).

The goal is to score the maximum possible number of points. The points of each player are summed at the end of the game and are attributed for the number of their concessions, for their political influence and for the supremacy in every three kinds of resources.

The game can be played from 2 to 6 players but it has a solitaire mode also.

Konsorcjum is language independent and comes with Polish, French, English, Spanish and Portuguese rules.

boardgame.name: Shattered Throne
boardgame.description:
Shattered Throne is the first expansion to the Planet Masters dicegame. This optional set of rules explains how to use the new dice.

Three new alien races with special abilities are available to the players. A new central planet is added to the dice pool and players can now invest in technology advances.

Background story:
The central government on Solium Sphaera has fallen. The planet is in turmoil. Social unrest divides the galaxy. The all consuming technology race between the empires has shattered the symbolic throne. Rivalry between the empires has never been this tense. Fleet sizes are rising. The amount of weapons is growing. The empire with the most advanced technological knowledge will seize control of the central megaplanet Solium Sphaera. He who controls Solium Sphaera reigns the universe.

boardgame.name: Huida de Silver City
boardgame.description:
Huida de Silver City (trad. Escape From Silver City) is the board game about survival, where zombies will hunt you without rest through streets and buildings, where there is no such thing as endless ammo and you never know what could be awaiting round the corner. Embody one of the outbreak survivors and cooperate with your partners so you can manage to leave the city before time runs out. You should be careful, though, because one of them looks a little bit ill and the girl was bitten a while ago… and she is anxiously staring at that bleeding wound in your arm. Maybe it’s just better save her the suffering with a bullet, you can make it yourself after all… or maybe not…?

Includes a large survivor-styled board, 30 personalized standups counters to represent characters and zombies, two dice: one eight-sided and another one six-sided, 93 cards, plenty of items to represent weapons and objects in general, 7 customized characters sheets, comprehensive rulebook with a fair amount of quests aside the main game.

The approach is simple... we have to flee the city. There are three ways to escape: land, sea and air. The last one is only available if between players is the character of the pilot. The other two are available ... as long as the ship does not leave nor the military blow the bridge to contain the outbreak. Do not forget that the transport may have limited seats.

And on the way? Zombies, hidden areas which reveal themselves by the survivors approaching. But beware! these areas may contain more zombies or obstacles that force us to get round. Also, there are many common and special buildings that we can loot- Only if we are not eaten- looking for weapons, equipment and medkits. Meanwhile, zombies are surrounding us, they corner us, hit us… they also bite us so we can get infected!! of course the rest of the team doesn't need to know, right?

boardgame.name: Я твоя понимай
boardgame.description:
The legendary Sannikov Land is discovered at last! Civilization ambassadors from all over the world move to the small piece of land lost somewhere in the Arctic. The are ready to offer the aboriginal Onkilon tribe various civilization achievements, from clock and football to submarines and atheism, as an exchange for the natural resources of the island. But still, it’s quite necessary for envoys at least to explain the indigenes what are they talking about before persuading them to buy all these surely useful miracles of culture, science and engineering because the only way to talk to the Onkilons is in primitive pictograms which represent simple words such as “fish”, “mother”, “egg”, “cold” or “above”.

My Understands You is a board game of associations and creative thinking. Players one after another take a role of civilization ambassador, who should explain any expression of the modern world using simple images. Others play as the Onkilons and try to guess what the guest of the Big world is talking about. Victory points charge by right conjectures and understandable explanations. When everyone will play as an envoy for 2 to 5 times, depending to the number of players, the game ends and the winner is defined according to the earned points.

At the game beginning each player gets a set of the voting tiles with the numbers from 1 to 6 on them and 3 stake tiles: smoked herring, reindeer hide and mammoth tusk. By the way, players acquire 3 big cards with civilization achievements, 2 words on each (for example, “oil derrick”, “backpack”, “deodorant”, “calculator”) and 6 small cards with pictograms (such as “woman”, “bird”, “loud”, “night”).

Each turn the envoy puts his achievement cards in a column. Upper word or phrase is counted as the first, the one under it as the second and all way down to the lower as the sixth one. Then the envoy decides which of the achievements he will explain with the gained pictograms. He should use 2 or 3 small cards: for example, “water”, “fire” and “below” for “oil derrick”. After the decision about the achievement and its explanation he puts the needed small cards with face up and the number tile face down.

Other players acting as the Onkilons join the round. They try to guess which of 6 achievements the presenter is trying to show. They find the word or phrase on the big cards that is the most suitable for the played pictograms and lay out the appropriate number tiles face down as well. Also the indigenes need to use one of the stake tiles. Victory points depend on the stake if the word hypothesis will be right: 1 point for a herring, 2 for a hide and 3 for a tusk.

When all the Onkilons have made their choice, everyone turns the voting tiles face up to see who guessed the achievement correctly. If all the players guessed or nobody did (in other words, the explanation was very clear or too complicated), tribesmen get 1 point each and the ambassador has nothing. If the right choice was made only by few natives, they get points according to their stakes and the envoy gains points for the biggest stake of the correct answer.
Ex-presenter takes new cards in exchange for used and hand over the turn.

My Understands You suits for the company of friends and for families as well. The most comfortable gameplay is for the 3-4 players – everyone can be a presenter for enough turns. Still the game can become longer for more player as well: achievement cards can be played for another round. Even if you’ll get the same words, the explanations can be fully different so it will let you discover lots of imagination inside your mind that you didn’t even suspect of.

boardgame.name: Paddy Griffith's Napoleonic Wargaming for Fun
boardgame.description:
From the publisher:"
In the early days of ‘modern’ wargaming, Napoleonic games were tremendously popular. They allowed the new, not necessarily young, wargamer to fight the glorious actions they had heard about in their school history lessons. Often starting with the Battle of Waterloo as their first action, the general would deploy his hastily painted soldiers from Airfix’s Napoleonic range. Airfix offered British and French infantry, as well as cavalry and guns for both sides.

Napoleonic tactics were simple in principle, but were hard to master in practice; for example infantry in a line maximized its firepower, but was vulnerable to cavalry. Changing to a square kept the infantry safe from the cavalry, but made them vulnerable to artillery and reduced their musketry to ¼ of the unit’s strength2. The games, just like the battles of history, were all about combining the efforts of the infantry, cavalry and artillery using ‘combined arms tactics’ to sweep the enemy away. The key problem with these games was the ‘helicopter overview’ of the action the players had of their largely divisional sized games. While representing the battles of the Napoleonic Wars in some ways, they did not recreate experience of the commanders of the time.

Paddy Griffith’s excellent book aimed to fill the gap and offer no less than seven different sets of rules to simulate the experience of command at different levels. Just as the early wargamers took the Airfix Napoleonic’s and converted them for use in a wide range of periods, the ideas offered by Paddy in these rules have equal potential to transform any wargamer’s tabletop experience. I am very pleased for the opportunity to reprint this classic work.

This book contains no less than seven sets of rules:

Skirmish level

Divisional game

Brigade game

Army level game

Generalship game

Map Kriegsspiel

Tactic Exercises Without Troops
"

A standalone miniatures wargame of future air superiority from One Pound Wargames, AirFrame allows players to assemble and customize their formation using existing air combat models from their collection. The game focuses on tactical manoeuvre and resource management in the 3-dimensional battlespace. AirFrame can also be combined with MechaWar for combined arms battles.

boardgame.name: Conspiracies
Συνωμοσίες
boardgame.description:
Conspiracies is the first installment in the Conspiracies series of full motion video adventure games. Conspiracies was developed by Anima Interactive.

Story
The game is set in the 21st century, where the human population suffers from a number of problems, including overpopulation, poverty, organized crime, and depression. Earth has dissolved into a federation of cities. The game is specifically set in Greece, where each city-state has its own governor and local government. However, this is overshadowed by a coalition of political lobbies, the big companies, the organized crime, that imposes their own reality.

Nick Delios, the protagonist, was originally in the academic world, but left it after being kicked out of his team. He eventually becomes a detective, specializing in cases of industrial espionage. When Thanos Pekas, Police Inspector and an old friend, asks him unofficially to help him solve a murder case of a small time crook, Delios accepts. He soon learns that the case is far more complex than he thought, involving multiple conspiracies.

Source: Wikipedia, "Conspiracies (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: SQUAR3
SQUARE
boardgame.description:
SQUAR3 (pronounced "Square") is a small but complex tactical tile laying game for two to four players. The players take turn placing square tiles on a 3x3 grid that forms the game board. Each tile has a point value and will influence all adjacent tiles. The players also place gems on top of these tiles to claim them for the final scoring. Some of the tiles have special actions that the player claiming that tile can use.

SQUAR3 is similar to games like Isis & Osiris or Go as the placement of tiles and player pieces is crucial for scoring the most points. A further depth of play stems from the orientation of each tile, the layering of tiles and the management of the actions available to each player.

Games of SQUAR3 can last for only a couple of turns or up to 30 min and can be quite mind-burning.

boardgame.name: Undead Escape
boardgame.description:
Undead Escape is a cooperative styled map building game designed for 2 to 5 players. In Undead Escape, one player plays as the human character, whose goal is to set enough fires to burn the zombie's factory to the ground. The remaining players will play as zombies doing everything they can to thwart the human player.

The game is built using pieces of the factory floor, which includes 16 movement spaces and locations for items. Items are placed face down and must be discovered by the players and stored in inventory and eventually used or destroyed depending on their player type.

Zombies will attempt to find newspapers and throw them into one of two water barrels randomly placed on the map. The human player attempts to find pieces needed to make fires, such as newspaper and matches, or a molotov cocktail. When the human player has enough items to start a fire, he must get to one of the fire locations on the map and light it.

To make things even more difficult for the human player, the zombies may also stash other items in their inventory, in which the player can only get back by attacking and winning a battle.

Metro City is redeveloping an old industrial district for mixed use (residential, commercial and industrial) and the mayor is offering bonuses to two developers for aesthetic completion of key streets. Can you win greater bonuses than your competitor by strategically building homes, offices, stores, courthouses, parks and malls in ways that upset your opponent’s plans for the city?

The city district is a 6 x 5 grid with 11 named streets. Each street has a mayor's bonus associated with it, from $1 to $15, drawn randomly at the start of the game. Players try to develop each street better than their opponent to claim its bonus.

Each player keeps a hand of 5 Building tiles out of 20 available to them. When placing a tile on an empty city block, if the tile completes a street (a row or column) they compare the value of their Buildings on the street to their opponent's Buildings to determine who wins the bonus. A straightforward comparison simply involves adding the number of each tile: Residential Buildings count from 1 to 5, Commercial Buildings count from 2 to 6 and Industrial Buildings count from 3 to 7. However, four types of special tiles change how the bonus is determined: a Park or Mall prevents either player's Industrial Buildings from counting towards the bonus on a street; a Power Plant or Mall prevents Residential Buildings from counting towards the bonus. Finally, the Courthouse allows the player to switch the bonuses of two streets.

Instead of placing a tile on an empty block, a player can discard a Currency token and build over a block they have already developed.

Whoever has the most money wins, and earns a key to the city from the mayor!

boardgame.name: Babes in the Woods
boardgame.description:
Objective: players striving to be the first to reach center and back out again.
- moving by turns -
each player moves according spinner, starting from a pink corner space; each player attempts to move towards the center space - called 'Heart of the Woods'. Red spaces on the board must be reached by exact spin in order to move in (later out) of the circle; once reaching the centre, players then turn around and move back out to any of the (pink) starting spaces.

boardgame.name: Road Wolf
boardgame.description:
Road Wolf is a free, home made, tabletop, turn based game of highway combat. Players choose vehicles, crew, and components and engage each other in high-speed scenarios on the road.

Physical components include a road (easy to make your own), vehicles (modified Matchbox or Hot Wheels cars work fine), dice, measuring sticks, record sheets for vehicles, and counters for crew and equipment (downloadable for free).

Players choose a scenario and purchase vehicles as described by the scenario. Most scenarios pit one player (or team of players) against another, with different win conditions depending on the scenario.

Unlike many vehicle games that rely on arena combat, Road Wolf follows vehicles traveling down a long, dangerous road. Movement is relative to the other vehicles, as all vehicles are assumed to be hurtling forward down the road, represented by a "road" move at the end of each turn. Hazards such as bridges or debris can move "towards" the vehicles during the road move, as can immobilized vehicles.

Each turn, vehicles get two actions to spend moving, shooting, or other actions. Vehicles may Ram or Melee each other as part of a move action, encouraging close combat. Degrees of success can damage or destroy vehicles or crew, or cause wipeout checks that can lead to lost ground or even chain reaction crashes.

boardgame.name: Mico
boardgame.description:
This game is played with 2 or more players, and 1 or more standard decks of cards.

After shuffling the cards, one card must be hidden. Then each player receives 9 cards, and the remaining cards forms the stack. Each player must try to make combinations of 3 cards, either 3 of the same number, or 3 cards in sequence. The combinations must be discarded. After make all possible combinations with the cards in hand, the players must take cards of the stack in order to make new combinations. All players can play simultaneously; there is no order of play.

When the stack run out of cards, the players, starting with the dealer and continuing in clockwise order, take cards of the player to the right (without see the cards of the player).

At the end, one player will remain with the last card in hand, and this card must be the same of the card hidden at the start (if not, somebody have make a mistake). This player is the winner.
